item.title: First blog post
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded: This is your very first post. Click the Edit link to modify or delete it, or start a new post. If you like, use this post to tell readers why you started this blog and what you plan to do with it.

item.title: Critical Behavior from Deep Dynamics: A Hidden Dimension in Natural Language
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Henry Lin and Max Tegmark https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.06737v1.pdf
  • Language cannot be explained by markov models because of its recursive nature.
  • LSTM can pick up on some of this but is not perfect.
  • They define a new method for testing improvements in the statistics of lstm.
Why is natural language so hard? The old answer was that language is uniquely human. The new answer is that at least part of the difficulty is that natural language is a critical system, with long-ranged correlations that are difficult for machines to learn.
Why are machines bad at natural languages, and why are they good? The old answer is that Markov models are simply not brain/human-like, whereas neural nets are more brain-like and hence better. The new answer is that Markov models or other 1-dimensional models cannot exhibit critical behavior, whereas neural nets and other deep models (where an extra hidden dimension is formed by the layers of the network) are able to exhibit critical behavior
. How can we know when machines are bad or good? The old answer is to compute the loss function. The new answer is to also compute the mutual information as a function of separation, which can immediately show how well the model is doing at capturing correlations on different scales.

item.title: Adversarially Learned Inference
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
https://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.00704v1.pdf https://ishmaelbelghazi.github.io/ALI/
  • The adversarially learned inference (ALI) model is a deep directed generative model which jointly learns a generation network and an inference network using an adversarial process.
  • objective function involves no explicit reconstruction loop
  • expense of making some mistakes in capturing exact object placement, color, style and (in extreme cases) object identity
  • Independant simultaneous release: https://arxiv.org/abs/1605.09782
    • Bidirectional GAN

item.title: InfoGAN: Interpretable Representation Learning by Information Maximizing Generative Adversarial Nets
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Xi Chen†‡, Yan Duan†‡, Rein Houthooft†‡, John Schulman†‡, Ilya Sutskever‡ , Pieter Abbeel†‡
  • Information theoretic extention to the GAN
    • Maximizes mutual information between latent variables (z) and the observation (x)
    • This produces neurons who represent high level information
  • http://www.inference.vc/infogan-variational-bound-on-mutual-information-twice/
    • Claims that GANs are minimizing a lower bound in the 'wrong direction'
    • Proposes that infoGANs fix this

item.title: Improved Techniques for Training GANs
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://arxiv.org/pdf/1606.03498v1.pdf Tim Salimans tim@openai.com Ian Goodfellow ian@openai.com Wojciech Zaremba woj@openai.com Vicki Cheung vicki@openai.com Alec Radford alec.radford@gmail.com Xi Chen peter@openai.com
  • Open AI paper with a number of improvements for GAN, which allows for larger networks (128x128)

item.title: Auto-Encoding Variational Bayes
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Original Paper on Variational Autoencoder
  • https://arxiv.org/pdf/1312.6114v10.pdf
  • Stochastic variational inference and learning algorithm
    • optimize variational lower bound using gradient descent
    • create continuous latent variables per datapoint
    • Posterior inference sits on top of variational representation to create approximate inference (recognition model)

item.title: Autoencoding beyond pixels using a learned similarity metric
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://arxiv.org/abs/1512.09300
  • Train a variational autoencoder and a GAN simultaneously
  • VAE error based upon deep layers in GAN
    • produces a 'learned similarity metric'

item.title: Cognitive Science in the era of Artificial Intelligence: A roadmap for reverse-engineering the infant language-learner
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.08723v1.pdf
  • Creating a dataset using wearable sensors to reverse engineer language acquisition
  • Proposes a method to Reverse Engineer language acqusition
  • Reviews proposed infant learning mechanisms
  • Breaks Machine Learning into three problems:
    • Syntax, Lexicon, Speech
  • Challenges in 'bootstrapping' learning
  • Challenging current psychological theories
    • Are phonemes good units?
      • Lee & Glass, 2012 say that to find phoneme size units you would need good priors
    • Statistical learning is insufficient alone to learn word boundaries
  • infants start differentiating native from foreign consonants and vowels at 6 months, but continue to fine tune their phonetic categories well after the first year of life (e.g., Sundara, Polka, & Genesee, 2006)
  • they start learning about the sequential structure of phonemes (phonotactics, see Jusczyk, Friederici, Wessels, Svenkerud, & Jusczyk, 1993) way before they are done acquiring the phoneme inventory (Werker & Tees, 1984)
  • [Language] acquisition takes places at all levels more or less simultaneously, in a gradual and largely overlapping fashion
  • The third requirement comes down to ‘desupervising’ machine learning algorithms, i.e. to have them learn latent linguistic representations instead of force-feeding these representations through expert annotations

item.title: ToDo:
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Vallabha, McClelland, Pons, Werker, & Amano, 2007
    • also: McMurray, Aslin, & Toscano, 2009
    • http://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.08723v1.pdf and Swingley claim they they still need to be tested on real datasets
  • (Maye, Werker, & Gerken, 2002
  • Saffran, Aslin, & Newport, 1996
  • Eimas paper
  • Artificial Grammer Learning
    • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_grammar_learning
  • Lee, O’Donnell & Glass, 2015
    • Propose a model of learning words and phonemes jointly from raw speech
  • Thiolliere et al., 2015
    • Deep neural network allows for discovery of words and phonemes synergy
  • Varadarajan, Khudanpur, and Dupoux (2008)
    • a clustering algorithm based on Hidden Markov Models and Gaussian mixtures does not converge on phonetic segments, but rather, on much shorter (30 ms), highly context-sensitive acoustic events (from http://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.08723v1.pdf)
  • hauser chomsky fitch
  • Paper for cog neuro?
  • Randy's papers...
  • Iverson and Kuhl 1996/2003
    • http://ucelinks.cdlib.org:8888/sfx_local?sid=google&auinit=P&aulast=Iverson&atitle=Influences+of+phonetic+identification+and+category+goodness+on+American+listeners%E2%80%99+perception+of/r/and/l&id=doi:10.1121/1.415234&title=The+Journal+of+the+Acoustical+Society+of+America&volume=99&issue=2&date=1996&spage=1130&issn=0001-4966
  • All of Jordan's papers
    • The papers from my current notes...
  • http://arxiv.org/pdf/1607.08723v1.pdf
    • roadmap for artificial intelligence
  • http://jn.physiology.org/content/105/6/2634

    • Representation of speech categories in the primate auditory cortex

  • Maps and streams in the auditory cortex: nonhuman primates illuminate human speech processing.
    • http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19471271

item.title: Higher Order Recursive Markov models

item.content:encoded: • Using 1st order vs 2nd order vs 3rd order statistics - how do we build up recursive representations?

item.title: Visual Information Theory
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://colah.github.io/posts/2015-09-Visual-Information/
    • Brad recommends
      • http://math.ucr.edu/home/baez/information/information_geometry_8.html
  • Conditional Probability
    • `p(rain,coat)=p(coat)⋅p(rain | coat)p(rain,coat)=p(coat)⋅p(rain | coat)`
    • The probability that I'm going to be wearning a T-shirt given that it's sunny is high
    • The probability that it's sunny given that I'm wearing a T shirt is high:
  • Information can be represented as bits
  • The cost of a bit should be proportional to its frequency
  • Entropy is the optimal average 'area' of the Probability of X P(x), and the length of the code in bits L(x).
    •  
  • The cost of a code in bits should be proportional to its quantity
  • Calculating entropy
    • The cost of a message of length L is 1/2^L
      • This can be inverted to get the length of a message that costs a given amount:
        • Log2(1/cost)
        • Since cost is proportional to p(x), the length is log2(1/p(x))
    • The entropy of a probability distribution p, is the average message length using the best possible code, H(p)
      • It can be calculated like so:
  • Cross-Entropy H_p(q)
    • How well distribution A can be described in the code of distribution B
      • Cross entropy is the average length of message q(x) using the code for p(x)
    • Cross entropy is not symmetric:
      • Hq(p) ~= Hp(q)
    • The KL divergence Dq(p) is the difference between Hq(p) and H(p)
      • It can be seen as a measure for the distance between distributions

item.title: Zebra finches exhibit speaker-independent phonetic perception of human speech
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Verena R. Ohms, Arike Gill, Caroline A. A. Van Heijningen, Gabriel J. L. Beckers, Carel ten Cate
  • http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/277/1684/1003
  • Go-NoGo
  • Zebra finches  were trained on a go-nogo procedure to discriminate between minimal pairs in english - they showed speaker independent recognition.

item.title: The natural history of sound localization in mammals – a story of neuronal inhibition
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://journal.frontiersin.org/article/10.3389/fncir.2014.00116/full
  • There are probably more relevant papers than this, but I liked the figure
  • Diagram of convergent evolution of the tympanic membrane in humans and songbirds

item.title: BIRDSONG AND HUMAN SPEECH: Common Themes and Mechanisms
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Doupe and Kuhl 1999
  • Parallels in human language acqusition and birdsong acquisition
  • Breaks song into
    • Production
    • Perception
  • Vocalizations are important in the context of others
  • It's important to hear one's own vocalizations
    • babbling
  • Innate predisposition to sound categories in infants and birds
  • Perceptual learning modifies innate predispositions
    • Songbirds first learn the subset of all possible vocalizations of a species (Marler 1970b)
Innate predispositions in infants
  • infants respond to the differences between phonetic units used in all of the world's languages, even those of languages they have never heard (Eimas 1975a, b;, Streeter 1976; for review see Kuhl 1987)
  • Very young infants not only perceive sounds categorically (Eimas et al 1971, Eimas 1975a) but also demonstrate the phenomenon for sounds from languages they have never heard as well as for sounds from their native language (Streeter 1976, Lasky et al 1975).
    • (chinchillas and monkeys) respond to the same discontinuities in speech that human infants do (Kuhl & Miller 1975;, Kuhl & Padden 1983),
    • Initial theories had argued that humans were endowed at birth with “phonetic feature detectors” that defined all possible phonetic units across languages (Eimas 1975b).
birdsong and language share is the conspicuous timing and ordering of components on a timescale longer than that of the syllable. Song syllables are usually grouped together to form phrases or “motifs” (Figure 2), which can be a series of identical or different syllables.
At a higher level of language analysis, there is some evidence that children exposed only to simple “pidgin” languages, and deaf children exposed to no acoustic or sign language, develop some elements (words or gestures, respectively) and order them in a way that is consistent with a rudimentary grammar (Pettito 1993,Bickerton 1990, Goldin-Meadow & Mylander 1998). It remains disputed, however, whether this reflects an innate model specific to language (Chomsky 1981, Fodor 1983) or a more general innate human capacity to learn to segment and group complex sensory inputs (Elman et al 1996,Bates 1992).

item.title: A role for the developing lexicon in phonetic category acquisition.
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/24219848 http://www.socsci.uci.edu/~lpearl/courses/psych215L_2015fall/presentations/Georgina-SpeechPerception.pdf
  • Releated to Swingley word learning review paper
  • We use a Bayesian model to illustrate how feedback from segmented words might constrain phonetic category learning by providing information about which sounds occur together in words
  • word-level information can successfully disambiguate overlapping English vowel categories
  • Provides a framework for how we might incorporate top-down constraints in phoneme category learning

item.title: Discriminative Deep Metric Learning for Face Verification in the Wild
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2014/papers/Wang_Learning_Fine-grained_Image_2014_CVPR_paper.pdf
  • A method for learning similarity based upon deep learning
  • Using deep learning to determine if an image is of the same thing
    • The problem with this, is we need to know if sounds are the same or different
  • Similar: http://www.cv-foundation.org/openaccess/content_cvpr_2014/papers/Wang_Learning_Fine-grained_Image_2014_CVPR_paper.pdf

item.title: Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Matthew Adam Miller http://lib.dr.iastate.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1813&context=etd
  • Solid review of some important topics in infant phoneme recognition
  • TODO: full review
  • Review section has 2 components
    • Infant word segmentation
      • Conclusions
        • there are several mechanisms for word discovery
        • All but 2 rely on prior knowledge
          • isolated words
            • could provide basis for other methods
          • statistical learning
            • however a more powerful form is needed (LSTM??)
    • Word segmentation with upsupervised models
  • Method
    • Use statistical learning to segment speech
    • Voting experts algorithm
      • 2 information theoretic properties
        • Low internal information
          • e.g. high probability sequences
        • high boundary entropy
          • e.g. very unlikely to predict next object in sequence
          • (how are these 2 things different?)
    • They suggest improvements on voting experts using sliding windows and hierarchy
  • it is well known that infants learn the words that their parents use in isolation much faster than other words [Brent and Siskind (2001); Bortfeld et al. (2005)]
  • Approximately 9% of words in infant directed speech are spoken in isolation [Brent and Siskind (2001)].
  • Allophonic variation helps can be a cue to segment words
    • The pronunciation of a phoneme varies based on its position within a word [Krakow (1999)] and this may help children find word boundaries [Church (1987)]. For instance, the sound made by a ‘t’ is usually aspirated at the beginning of a word, but not at the end. Notice the difference in pronunciation between the ‘t’ in “tall” and the ‘t’ in “bat.”
  • there are several different cues present in language streams that can be used to find word boundaries, and children seem to be sensitive to many of them [Jusczyk (1999); Mattys et al. (2005)]. Unfortunately, most of them require at least moderate segmentation proficiency before they can be employed. That is, they are methods of improving segmentation as opposed to learning to do it from scratch
  • multiple studies have shown that the direct application of the T P strategy performs poorly when used to segment phonetic transcripts of speech [Cairns and Shillcock (1997); Gambell and Yang (2008)].
    • a very high percentage of common words contain only one syllable
    • the original conclusion that word-internal transitions should have higher probabilities than word-external ones is not always true in practice

item.title: Phonological parsing in speech recognition
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=avbjBwAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PR11&dq=Phonological+parsing+in+speech+recognition&ots=HC7y5fqKpr&sig=WUvc3UEeUXJxJU7JPEnvJ4p1xvc#v=onepage&q=Phonological%20parsing%20in%20speech%20recognition&f=false Church, K. W. (1987)
  • Quoted from "Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm"
    • The pronunciation of a phoneme varies based on its position within a word [Krakow (1999)] and this may help children find word boundaries [Church (1987)]. For instance, the sound made by a ‘t’ is usually aspirated at the beginning of a word, but not at the end. Notice the difference in pronunciation between the ‘t’ in “tall” and the ‘t’ in “bat.”

item.title: Statistical Learning by 8-Month Old Infants
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://www.atsweb.neu.edu/hlittlefield/CourseDocs/Acq/SaffranEtAl-1996.pdf
  • Saffran, aslin, newport, 1996
  • Transitional probabilities provide an mechanism for infant word segmentation
  • 2 minutes of exposure
  • Experience dependent mechanism
  • Statistical learning was supposedly predicted many times over:
  • The idea that infants use statistical cues to segment speech streams has a long history [Chomsky (1955); Harris (1955); Hayes and Clark (1970); Wolff (1977); Pinker (1984); Goodsitt et al. (1993)].
    • From "Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm"
  • Statistical learning is multisensory:
    • visual examples:
      • [Saffran et al. (1997, 1999); Fiser and Aslin (2002); Kirkham et al. (2002)

item.title: Infants' Preference for the Predominant Stress Patterns of English Words
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://pubman.mpdl.mpg.de/pubman/item/escidoc:68819:4/component/escidoc:68820/Cutler_1993_Infants&
  • Jusczky, Cutler, Rendanz, 1993
  • Stress patterns play a role in segmenting utterances into words
  • The majority of english words have a stressed strong initial syllable
  • Experiment 1
    • American 9mo infants listen longer to strong/weak stress patterns.
  • Experiment 2
    • 6mo show no difference
  • Experiment 2
    • 9mo show strong weak preference even when speech is low pass filtered
      • (why did they do that?)
  • Importantly, the use of a prosidic (metrical) cue is learned - as it differs across languages, meaning infants would have already needed to learn a significant number of words to make use of this heuristic.

item.title: Mechanisms and constraints in word segmentation.
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Gambell, T. and Yang, C. (2008). Mechanisms and constraints in word segmentation. Manuscript, Yale University
  • Referenced by "Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm"
  • Children assume that one syllable per word is emphasized
    • This does not tell us when the word begins and ends, but it gives us a rough estimate, and tells us about how many words are in an utterance

item.title: Infants′ Sensitivity to the Sound Patterns of Native Language Words
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• P.W. Jusczyk,A.D. FriedericiJ.M.I. Wessels,V.Y. Svenkerud,A.M. Jusczyk (1993)
  • Infants at 9 months old know phonetic patterns of native language - how consonental phonemes sit together
  • American 9mo  listened significantly longer to English sound patterns than dutch sound patterns
    • Dutch children did the opposite
    • No preference for low pass filtered versions of words
      • This suggests that they were listening to phonotactics, rather than prosody
      • words differed only in their phonotactic properties
  • With prosodic differences - 9mos listened significantly longer to english words
  • This is all because consonantal patterns are fairly constrained within language

item.title: Formal vs. functional considerations in phonology
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• https://books.google.com/books?id=_drSeCMfIkEC&lpg=PA325&ots=Tr4NtVK0iM&dq=Formal%20vs.%20functional%20considerations%20in%20phonology&lr&pg=PA325#v=onepage&q=Formal%20vs.%20functional%20considerations%20in%20phonology&f=false
not all possible consonant clusters are “legal” in onsets and codas in English
  • Halle, 1970s
  • From "Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm"
    • not all possible consonant clusters are “legal” in onsets and codas in English. For instance, a syllable cannot start with two guttural stops. Therefore the consonant cluster “pg” would not be a valid onset. In fact, there are not a lot of consonant clusters that are allowed to serve as onsets [Halle (1978)].
  • Part of the justification for why infants can differentiate languages based on phonotactics (Jusczyk et al. (1993b, 1994);)- but provides a basis for word beginnings

item.title: The role of exposure to isolated words in early vocabulary development
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• infants under 9 mos
  • Isolated words are a reliable feature of speech
    • often isolated words are heard in repeat
    • children more often produce words that their mother speaks in isolation
  • Major questions
    • Are isolated words a normal and reliable feature of spontaneous infant-directed speech?
    • Do children hear repeated instances of a variety of distinct words in isolation?
    • Does a significant proportion of children's earliest vocabularies consist of words that they have heard in isolation?
    • Does exposure to isolated instances of a word predict later knowledge of that word, above and beyond total frequency of exposure?

item.title: Phonotactic cues for segmentation of fluent speech by infants
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Mattys and Jusczyk 2001
  • 9 month olds make use of phonotactic (phoneme combination) cues to segment words from fluent speech
  • Used Headturn preference procedure
  • C(onsonant)V(owel)C(onsonant) stimulus are more preferable to CC stimulus or CCVCC.
    • CC transitions are often heard between, but not within, words.
  • “help the chap get out of the car"
    • "pg" in chap get, is an easy segmentation point if you know english, because they don't occur together
      • (from 'Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm')
  • the results suggest that 9-month-olds use probabilistic phonotactics to segment speech into words and that high-probability between-word clusters are interpreted as both word onsets and word offsets.

item.title: Learning words from sights and sounds: a computational model
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0364021301000611
  • Deb K Roy, Alex P Pentland
  • Implementation of an RNN model of word acquisition which uses visual and auditory input\
http://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0364021301000611-gr1.jpg http://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0364021301000611-gr1.jpg

item.title: A Bayesian framework for word segmentation: Exploring the effects of context
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Goldwater, Griffiths, Johnson 2009
    • similar to earlier (2006?) paper by same authors
  • http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0010027709000675
  • Bayesian model for word segmentation
  • Assuming words are independant causes undersegmentation - "whatsthat"
    • Assuming words are predictive, segmentation is much more accurate

item.title: An Efficient, Probabilistically Sound Algorithm for Segmentation and Word Discovery
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Brent, 1999
Unlike printed English, in which words are separated by blank spaces, speech does not contain any reliable acoustic demarcation of word boundaries
  • First bayesian model of word segmentation
  • INCDROP
  • referenced in "Unsupervised segmentation of audio speech using the Voting Experts algorithm"
  • Uses text

item.title: Training GAN with spatial pooling
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded: Train network using pooling, so that spatial locations become less important, but filter level statistics stay important.

item.title: Meeting with Tim, 8/8/16
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Take 4 (already trained) motifs: ABCD
  • Create a grid between the 4 points
    • 5x5 grid
    • Treat this grid as an equidistant space
  • For each point on the grid, compute similarity measure (perceptual distance) between elements
    • for multidimensional scaling
Method:
  • Generate 5x5 grid
  • create new 'test' class for Same-Different task
    • test class gets no reward
  • 5*5 = grid
    • 5x5^2 = correlation matrix
      • (5*5) ^2 * 10 = 6250 = rough number of repeats needed to build MDS

item.title: Targets for a Comparative Neurobiology of language
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Introduction
  • Segmentation
    • General
      • Does language exist on some continuum with non-human animals, or is it categorically distinct
      • Instead of asking if there are human unique abilities, study prerequisites for learning that animals do have
      • Jusczky 1999
        • suggests statistical and prosodic cues play a large role in segmentation
    • Neurobiology
    • Songbirds

item.title: From Acoustic Segmentation to Language Processing: Evidence from Optical Imaging
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2912026/
  • Review paper
  • Review of 'otical methods' (NIRS) in studying hemispheric differences during segmentation and feature analysis for language development

item.title: Representation of speech categories in the primate auditory cortex
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Yale Cohen, etc
  • http://jn.physiology.org/content/105/6/2634
 
  • Prior work shows that "neurons in the prefrontal cortex reflect monkeys' decisions during categorical judgments"
  • Current work STG
    • Match to category task.
  • a “ventral” pathway processes a sound's nonspatial attributes, such as its identity

item.title: Maps and streams in the auditory cortex: nonhuman primates illuminate human speech processing
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v12/n6/full/nn.2331.html
  • Primate auditory cortex is hierarchically organized
  • Claims animals do not have the same recursive or combinatorial power as humans
  • topographic mapping
  • streams (what and where)
  • streams run in two directions - looping from auditory cortex, frontal cortex, motor cortex, and parietal cortex

item.title: Mechanisms and streams for processing of “what” and “where” in auditory cortex
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.pnas.org/content/97/22/11800.full
  • Rauschecker
  • Similar to the what and where pathways in vision, the auditory cortex also has what and where pathways

• Freedman, Riesenhuber, Poggio, Miller

item.title: Correlations and Neuronal Population Information
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Our situation is perhaps analogous to pre-Newtonian physics, which attempted to understand the movements of the stars and planets through extremely careful and detailed measurements. Ultimately, however, orbits were understood in a straightforward way with Newtonian physics. We see a risk that we—like pre-Newtonian physicists, but abetted by much more powerful instrumentation—will drown in a sea of description, measuring and characterizing population activity patterns rather than understanding the computations and functions they underlie.
  • http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/pdf/10.1146/annurev-neuro-070815-013851
  • Different Types of Correlations (or functions for correlations)
    • Quantifying the degree of similarity
      • e.g. orientation tuing in V1 neurons
    • Minimization of correlations is involved in efficient representation
      • Reduce representational redundancy
    • Patterened Correlation: Quantify similarity of population response to different stimuli
      • e.g. two different oders
    • Response variability shared between neurons
      • neurons respond variable accross presentations
      • some of this variability is shared between neighboring neurons
      • we use pearson correlation
        • spike count correlation
  • Background
    • Monkey MT study
      • variable responses of MT neurons limit information provided about external stimulus
      • responses of many neurons can be pooled to get a precise estimate of the stimulus
        • if each neurons variability is independent (?)
      • Response variability is correlated between similar neurons
        • so you lose information by pooling signals of too many neurons
    • Weighting neurons equally (averaging) is not always a good strategy
      • weighting based on a linear model is better and learnable
    • Linear Fisher Information
      • measures the smallest change in the stimulus that can be distinguished reliably with an optimal linear decoder
      • Testing how good an LM of A predicting B could be used for the Z space analysis
        • f' : the derivative of the turning curve with respect to stimulus variable of interest
        • Q : response covariance matrix
      • For a homogeneous population, Fisher information is reduced by correlations that are strongest between pairs of neurons with similar preferences, termed limited-range correlations.

item.title: Neural representations of events arise from temporal community structure
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Anna C. Schapiro,1,2,* Timothy T. Rogers,3 Natalia I. Cordova,1,2 Nicholas B. Turk-Browne,1,2 and Matthew M. Botvinick1,2

    • background task of orientation
  • Present stimuli in fMRI
  • Neural network and temporal lobe show similar results

item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• largely based upon
    • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phonological_development

    • [phonotactics/phoneme sequencing] language specific babbling at ~10 months
      • Evidence for Language Specific Rhythmic Influences in the Reduplicative Babbling of French and English Learning Infants
    • Semantics
    • 4.5 month olds prefer listening to their own name over other names matched for stress patterns, as well as foils with opposite patterns

item.title: Speech perception in infants
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Eimas et al 1971
  • 1 month old infants show different sucking rate when category boundaries are traversed for speech

item.title: Acoustic determinants of infant preference for motherese speech
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Fernald, Kuhl
  • 1 month old infants prefer full speech signal to prosodic signal
  • 4 months olds prefer prosodic signal to full signal,not prosodic
  • This is taken as evidence that infants learn prosody between 1 and 4 months

item.title: The Vocal Repertoire of the Red Junglefowl: A Spectrographic Classification and the Code of Communication
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.jstor.org/stable/1368641?origin=crossref&seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents
  • Example of birds having semantic value for different communicative symbols
  • From wikipedia:
    •  Domestic chickenshave distinctive alarm calls for aerial and ground predators, and they respond to these alarm calls appropriately
  • Call Types
    • Brief, soft repetitive notes of low frequency are attraction calls
    • Loud harsh sounds with high frequencies are alarm cries
    • Harsh sounds emphasizing low frequencies are threat sounds. These rules hold for many other birds
    • Junglefowl also have special calls that appear to indicate well-being, or mild disturbance and frustration

item.title: Direct observation of syringeal muscle function in songbirds and a parrot
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Ole Næsbye Larsen, Franz Goller
  • Songbirds produce vocalizations by passing air though the medial and lateral labia on each side of the syrinx. 
    • This production is bilateral
  • From wikipedia:
    • Passerine birds produce song through the vocal organ, the syrinx, which is composed of bilaterally symmetric halves located where the trachea separates into the two bronchi. Using endoscopictechniques, it has been observed that song is produced by air passing between a set of medial and lateral labia on each side of the syrinx.

item.title: Neural lateralization of vocal control in a passerine bird
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Fernando Nottebohm 1971
  • Songbirds show neural lateralization - cutting out one side of the syrinx greatly reduces song, while the other does not
  • Waterschlager canary
  • Lesioning ipsilateral tracheosyringeal branch of hypoglossal nerve disables left or right syninx
    • Disabling the left syrinx strongly affects song, whereas the effect is weak on the right side

item.title: Right-side dominance for song control in the zebra finch
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Heather Williams,Linda A. Crane,Timothy K. Hale,Matthew A. Esposito, Fernando Nottebohm
  • From wikipedia:
    • Laterality of song control has been observed all the way into the higher vocal center (HVC) brain region; unilateral lesions to HVC produce lateralized effects in the temporal patterning of song in the zebra finch.
  • HVC lesions affect temporal patterning of birds song
    • Lesions to the right side caused greater changes in temporality

item.title: Precise auditory–vocal mirroring in neurons for learned vocal communication
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• J. F. Prather1, S. Peters2, S. Nowicki1,2 & R. Mooney1
  • Neurons in HVC that project to Area X respond only to note sequences that the bird itself produces
  • Swamp sparrow
  • Conclude that
    • singing-related activity in these cells is compared to auditory feedback to guide vocal learning.
  (image from wikipedia)

item.title: The Neural Basis of Birdsong
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Nottebohm
  • Describes to main songbird pathways
    • Posterior Descending Pathway (PDP)
      • needed for acquisition and production of learned song
    • Anterior Forebrain Pathway (AFP)
      • needed only for song acquisition
light = PDP, dark = AFP
  • PDP = direct pathway
  • AFP is similar to
    • mamallian pathway cortex to basal ganglia to thalamus to cortex

item.title: Infant's Recognition of the Sound Patterns of Their Own Names
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Mandel, Juseczyk, Pisoni
  • 4.5 month olds prefer listening to their own name over other names matched for stress patterns, as well as foils with opposite patterns

item.title: Interruption of a basal ganglia-forebrain circuit prevents plasticity of learned vocalizations
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Brainard & Doupe 2000
  • http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v404/n6779/full/404762a0.html
  • Deafening adult birds leads to song deterioration
    • lesioning LMAN (of anterior forebrain) halts that deterioration
    • This leads us to believe that LMAN is involved in instructive feedback (learning)
  • From wikipedia:
    • Brainard & Doupe (2000) posit a model in which LMAN (of the anterior forebrain) plays a primary role in error correction, as it detects differences between the song produced by the bird and its memorized song template and then sends an instructive error signal to structures in the vocal production pathway in order to correct or modify the motor program for song production

item.title: Phonetic Feature Encoding in Human Superior Temporal Gyrus
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Nima Mesgarani1,*, Connie Cheung1, Keith Johnson2, Edward F. Chang1,†
  • Superior Temporal Gyrus 
    • topographical representation for phonemes
    • Single electrodes show response selectivity to distinct phonemes

item.title: Perceptual mechanisms for individual vocal recognition in European starlings, Sturnus vulgaris
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• TIMOTHY Q. GENTNER & STEWART H. HULSE
  • Starlings are sensitive to the statistical relationships within motifs
    • Starlings are capable of individual recognition
      • this individual recognition appears to exist at the motif-level
  • Birds taught to differentiate one birds song from 3 others
    • 3 Groups:
      • own song group (males)
      • familiar song group (males)
      • unfamilar song group (females)
    • Test:
      • transferred to new natural stimuli
      • transferred to new synthetic stimuli (markov chains)
    • Results:
      • birds correctly identified song
        • individual vocal recognition
  • From 'Targets for a Comparative Neuroanatomy of language':
    • After being trained to classify song excerpts from different singers, starlings show sensitivity to both intra-motif temporal statistics and inter-motif statistics.
      • When sub-motif acoustical features are permuted, thus breaking down intra-motif statistical relationships, birds show a deficit in recognition
      • When asked to classify excerpts from the same birds but composed of novel motifs, however, birds perform equally well for excerpts with intact motifs and intramotif permutations

item.title: Neuronal populations and single cells representing learned auditory objects
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Frequency tuned responses of primary fibers in the eighth nerve give rise to increasingly complex “objects” at more central levels
  • Neurons are selective for learned conspecific vocalizations in adult animals
    • this is trained using operant conditioning

item.title: Perceptual classification based on the component structure of song in European starlings
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Timothy Q. Gentner and Stewart H. Hulse
  • Trained birds on identifying songs from one individual
    • Tested birds by replacing motifs with novel motifs, in song
      • Birds recognition ability scales linearly with number of novel motifs
        • birds are also making retroactive inferences

item.title: Recurrent processing during object recognition
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
Randall C. O’Reilly1,2†, Dean Wyatte1†, Seth Herd1, Brian Mingus1 and David J. Jilk2
  • Take a convolutional neural network (which is supposed to emulate the visual processing stream)
    • Add in semantic properties
    • Recognition performance is increased under partial occlusion 
    • Learned object recognition becomes more similar

item.title: Cog Neuro Starlings and Marmosets
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
The argument for why particular animals can be used as models of human behavior and/or neural function is based on shared characteristics at a particular level of the system. In the case of language, different species have been argued to be valuable models for its various constituent components. Select two examples discussed in class or the readings and make the case for why the species is or is not a good model of language. Your answer can use evidence from the behavioral and/or neural levels but must be compelling [5pts each, 10pts total].   Although humans alone produce language, many cognitive and physiological mechanisms which facilitate language are either preserved in our closest animal relatives, or evolved in parallel through convergent evolution in distal species. Each species used as a model for language acquisition provides its own pros and cons, and different species are chosen for questions that they are best suited to answer. I discuss here two major species, the European Starling (Sturnus vulgaris) and the Common Marmoset (Callithrix jacchus), and the questions which are easier and harder to address in each species. However, even the segmentation of components underlying is not an easy task. No clear boundaries exist between different cognitive mechanisms, and neural substrates underlying different functional regions of the human brain are highly interactive and appear to be involved in functions which are explicitly related to language. For example, Hickock and Poeppel’s (1) dual stream model for the cortical processing of speech are highly similar to Rauschecker’s (2) dual stream “what” and “where” model for auditory processing in the cortex, suggesting that brain regions highly involved in language have also existed for non-language functions. While sensory neuroscientists often identify as studying perception or production, linguists and cognitive psychologists will identify as studying semantics or syntax, developmental researchers parcellated themselves to acquisition, computational modellers tend to confine to speech recognition, and evolutionary biologists and psychologists will study the conservation of functions and regions. With each of these different perspectives, different species can be used for different reasons. For example, studying the evolution of the human vocal tract makes no sense in an evolutionary lineage completely divergent from humans (although the evolution of vocal learning, cognitive capacities, and sensory processing certainly do). Similarly vocal learning requires a species whose vocal productions are not deterministic, whereas perceptual category learning can be studied in species that produce no vocalizations.   Fig 1. Animal Models For language. Produced on (http://phylot.biobyte.de/) using NCBI taxonomy (http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/guide/taxonomy/) Common Marmoset The common marmoset is a new-world monkey native to the northeastern coast of Brazil. As with most primates, marmosets make use of vocalization for social reasons such as mating, and dominance hierarchy maintenance. Marmosets diverged from humans around 30 million years ago (3), and have recently had their entire genome sequenced (4), which like all primates is highly conserved with humans. Marmosets will also breed in captivity, and learn to communicate by vocalizing back and forth with their parents (5) making them an excellent model for vocal development. A benefit of the primate model is its conserved topography to human auditory processing streams. Because non-human primates have so many conserved cognitive and neural and behavioral similarities with humans, there are two paths which can easily be taken to explore the neural and cognitive basis of language: (1) What aspects of cognition are shared across humans and Marmosets, and (2) What aspects of cognition differ between humans and Marmosets. The first of these questions is more obvious. Because humans have language, and many of the structures which are important to language exist in non human primates, we can ask questions about how these processing streams interact in non-humans. For example, in exploring early auditory cortex in primates, we can ask questions about how voices are processed. Do auditory core regions show invariance to changes in pitch? Where do we begin to find regions which are selective to voices, and features of voices? Do early auditory areas represent information using a spectrotemporal receptive field which is analogous to the retinotopy of early visual areas? How does auditory invariance work, what are the pathways, and what function do each pathway appear to be serving? The similarity between human brains and primate brains, along with genetic tools that are becoming available in the Marmoset allow us to ask questions that address what each piece of the puzzle is doing, and how it works. However, the Marmoset model for language has its own drawbacks. Non-human primate vocalizations do not exhibit the complex patterning of human language, and as a result, while neural structures may exist to support some of the complexities of human language, getting Callitrichidae to demonstrate certain basics of temporal pattern learning have made them a challenging model to study temporal pattern learning with (e.g. Fitch and Hauser (6, 7) where songbirds have excelled (8, 9).   European Starling Songbirds most common ancestor with humans were alive in the early Mesozoic period, their ear evolved seperately from humans (10), they have no cortex and their brains contain approximately 10 million cells (11), as compared to the 636 million in Marmosets (12), and the 20 billion in adult humans. While it is clear that songbirds do not take the cake for the evolutionary model for human language, they do have a few major benefits over primates in studying cognition and physiology: they can perform complex sequence learning and production tasks, they are inexpensive to maintain, they train quickly (although the longer I’ve been working with birds, the more I’ve become apathetic to this claim), they learn complex temporal patterns, and computation in their pallium is segmented into nuclei which are well defined. The combination of these features make songbirds and excellent model for studying early language acquisition. A major unsolved problem that has received surprisingly little attention from machine learning, and cognitive modelling communities is zero-resource modelling of language acquisition, which can produce a learning trajectory which can mimic human infants who have not yet actually learned language. Songbirds provide an excellent medium from which to analyze the neural processing which underlie these cognitive behaviors, which primate researchers have had trouble finding a model for. Räsänen et al., (13) produced a paper for the Zerospeech 2015 challenge, in which researchers are asked to computationally discover words from the speech stream using zero prior knowledge. The following pipeline was used to discover words: This pipeline can be broken down into the following mechanisms: (1) Segment the speech stream based upon physical cues (2) Unsupervised clustering of acoustic features, (3) word segmentation through probabilistic segment co-occurance. Each of these elements exists in songbirds to some extent, making them an attractive model for early word acquisition. For example, birdsong is composed of hierarchically organized sound elements, which require fundamental unit (motif) segmentation initially discovered initially through physical cues (14). Categories of speech sounds can be learned by songbirds (15), and categories can be learned covertly through sequence level feedback (16). Finally, statistical learning, a simple form of N-gram discovery using co-occurance probabilities as a heuristic for learning rudimentary word boundaries (17), have been suggested in songbirds (18), although controls were not used in this study.  It is important to note however that these mechanisms are not well understood in human language acquisition, and likely much more goes into word discovery than this linear pipeline. This is not to say that the origins are shared with humans in any way, however time series context maintenance is theorized to involve striatal signalling for active maintenance with the frontal cortex, where functional (19) analogs have been proposed in songbirds (20), and striatum has largely been conserved between mammals and birds  (21). Potential mechanisms for computational models for word discovery are discussed in further detail by (22).   Although mechanisms used in any non-human species might explain phenomena which are used in language, there are many ways to skin a cat. While it is possible that convergent evolution can give rise to equivalent neural mechanisms to perform a cognitive task, convergent evolution can also give rise to entirely different mechanisms where analogies break down to the point of being unusable in explaining human cognition. While this is almost certainly the case with songbirds, it is also important to note that between humans and even their most common ancestor, the Chimpanzee (Pan troglodyte), the brain underwent significant changes, nearly quadrupling in size (Roth and Dick 2005), and any specific connections analogs found in other species should be considered with care.   Bibliography
  1. G. Hickok, D. Poeppel, The cortical organization of speech processing. Nat Rev Neurosci. 8, 393–402 (2007).
  2. J. P. Rauschecker, S. K. Scott, Maps and streams in the auditory cortex: nonhuman primates illuminate human speech processing. Nat Neurosci. 12, 718–724 (2009).
  3. S. I. Perez, M. F. Tejedor, N. M. Novo, L. Aristide, Divergence Times and the Evolutionary Radiation of New World Monkeys (Platyrrhini, Primates): An Analysis of Fossil and Molecular Data. PLoS ONE. 8, e68029 (2013).
  4. Marmoset Genome Sequencing and Analysis Consortium, The common marmoset genome provides insight into primate biology and evolution. Nat Genet. 46, 850–857 (2014).
  5. A. Pistorio, B. Vintch, X. Wang, Acoustic analysis of vocal development in a New World primate, the common marmoset (Callithrix jacchus) a). Journal of the Acoustical Society of … (2006) (available at http://scitation.aip.org/content/asa/journal/jasa/120/3/10.1121/1.2225899).
  6. W. T. Fitch, M. D. Hauser, Computational constraints on syntactic processing in a nonhuman primate. Science. 303, 377–380 (2004).
  7. A. Seed, M. Tomasello, Primate cognition. Top Cogn Sci. 2, 407–419 (2010).
  8. T. Q. Gentner, K. M. Fenn, D. Margoliash, H. C. Nusbaum, Recursive syntactic pattern learning by songbirds. Nature. 440, 1204–1207 (2006).
  9. V. Janik, P. Slater, The different roles of social learning in vocal communication. Anim Behav. 60, 1–11 (2000).
  10. B. Grothe, M. Pecka, The natural history of sound localization in mammals--a story of neuronal inhibition. Front Neural Circuits. 8, 116 (2014).
  11. K. Hinsch, G. K. H. Zupanc, Generation and long-term persistence of new neurons in the adult zebrafish brain: a quantitative analysis. Neuroscience. 146, 679–696 (2007).
  12. S. Herculano-Houzel, C. E. Collins, P. Wong, J. H. Kaas, Cellular scaling rules for primate brains. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 104, 3562–3567 (2007).
  13. O. Räsänen, G. Doyle, M. Frank, Unsupervised word discovery from speech using automatic segmentation into syllable-like units. Manuscript submitted for (2015) (available at http://users.spa.aalto.fi/orasanen/papers/zerospeech_sylseg_2015.pdf).
  14. J. T. Kiggins, J. A. Comins, T. Q. Gentner, Targets for a comparative neurobiology of language. Front Evol Neurosci. 4, 6 (2012).
  15. K. R. Kluender, R. L. Diehl, P. R. Killeen, Japanese quail can learn phonetic categories. Science. 237, 1195–1197 (1987).
  16. J. A. Comins, T. Q. Gentner, Pattern-Induced Covert Category Learning in Songbirds. Curr Biol. 25, 1873–1877 (2015).
  17. J. R. Saffran, R. N. Aslin, E. L. Newport, Statistical learning by 8-month-old infants. Science. 274, 1926–1928 (1996).
  18. M. Takahasi, H. Yamada, K. Okanoya, Statistical and Prosodic Cues for Song Segmentation Learning by Bengalese Finches (Lonchura striata var. domestica). Ethology. 116, 481–489 (2010).
  19. R. C. O’Reilly, M. J. Frank, Making working memory work: a computational model of learning in the prefrontal cortex and basal ganglia. Neural Comput. 18, 283–328 (2006).
  20. O. Güntürkün, The avian “prefrontal cortex” and cognition. Curr Opin Neurobiol. 15, 686–693 (2005).
  21. A. Reiner, L. Medina, C. L. Veenman, Structural and functional evolution of the basal ganglia in vertebrates. Brain Res Rev. 28, 235–285 (1998).
  22. M. Frank, Computational models of early language acquisition. Unpublished manuscript (2013) (available at https://langcog.stanford.edu/papers/F-underreview-b.pdf).
  23. A. Caramazza, D. Chialant, R. Capasso, G. Miceli, Separable processing of consonants and vowels. Nature. 403, 428–430 (2000).
  24. A. Caramazza, A. E. Hillis, Lexical organization of nouns and verbs in the brain. Nature. 349, 788–790 (1991).
  25. G. B. Cogan et al., Sensory-motor transformations for speech occur bilaterally. Nature. 507, 94–98 (2014).
  26. N. T. Sahin, S. Pinker, S. S. Cash, D. Schomer, E. Halgren, Sequential processing of lexical, grammatical, and phonological information within Broca’s area. Science. 326, 445–449 (2009).
27. P. S. Goldman-Rakic, Regional and cellular fractionation of working memory. Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A. 93, 13473–13480 (1996).

item.title: Birds have primate-like numbers of neurons in the forebrain

• Birds have higher neuronal densities than mammals

• Dezhe Z. Jina,1, Naotaka Fujiib,1, and Ann M. Graybielc,2
  • Neurons show time stamp encoding in basal ganglia and PFC
    • Supports reinforcement learning models
  • Record thousands of neurons in PFC and Striatum
    • DLPFC and Caudate Nucleus
    • Some neurons showed time stamp encodings
    • Subset of neurons exhibit time-stamp encoding
    • These neurons are predicted by reinforcement learning models

item.title: Syllable chunking in zebra finch (Taeniopygia guttata) song.
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/1395497
  • Williams H1, Staples K.
  • Syllables are incorporated by zebra finches as periods between silences
    • These syllables are actually chunks of syllables
  • Examined how young males copy chunks of tutor songs
    • found that segmentations were consistent
      • based upon long silences

item.title: Species-typical songs in white-crowned sparrows tutored with only phrase pairs.
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v432/n7018/full/nature02992.html
  • Gary J. Rose, Franz Goller, Howard J. Gritton, Stephanie L. Plamondon, Alexander T. Baugh & Brenton G. Cooper
  • Present developing sparrows with single pairs of syllables
    • developing sparrows incorporate those pairs into their song

item.title: Goldsmith (2010) notes, if you dig deep enough into any task in acquisition, it will become clear that in order to model that task e ectively, a model of every other task is necessary
item.dc:creator: timsainb

item.title: Rule Learning by Seven-Month-Old Infants
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• G. F. Marcus,* S. Vijayan, S. Bandi Rao, P. M. Vishton
  • Infants learn algebraic (ba,ta,mu = A, gi,po,bu = B) rules from grammar
  • Taught 7mo ABA vs ABB
    • categories of A and B were defined by syllables, where a subset of training data was withheld
      • Infants were able to learn what an 'A' or 'B' was, SRNs were not.

item.title: Birds – same thing, but different? Convergent evolution in the avian and mammalian auditory systems provides informative comparative models
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Christine Köppl
  • Birds basilar membranes are different than humans
  • birds arguably represent the most extreme case of hair cells using bundle motility for mechanical amplification at high frequencies, up to about 10 kHz
  • Birds diverged evolutionarily with humans at least 300 million years ago
  • Tympanic membranes evolved separately
  • Barn owls hear at very high frequencies, which maxes out around 10kHz
http://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378595510002133-gr4.jpg

item.title: Context-dependent categorical perception in a songbird
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Robert F. Lachlana,1,2 and Stephen Nowickia,b
  • http://www.pnas.org/content/112/6/1892.full.pdf
  • Swamp sparrows show context dependance in category perception
  • Sparrows reduce responsively to atypical notes

item.title: Unsupervised word discovery from speech using automatic segmentation into syllable-like units
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• A simple algorithm for word discovery
    • Find syllables
      • 3 methods:
        • envelope minima
        • maximal positive peaks in velocity of envelope
        • Aplitude envelope driven oscillator (Ghitza and Poeppel)
    • Cluster syllables
      • MFCC
        • 25ms window, 10ms step size
        • cepstral mean and variance normalization
      •  K-means
        • speaker specific
        • Q clusters
        • # of clusters = 30% of total syllables for talker
      • N-gram search
        • Start with longest recurring n-gram
          • remove all n-grams that occur at least twice
          • repeat down until unigrams

item.title: Japanese quail can learn phonetic categories
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• KR Kluender, RL Diehl, PR Killeen
  • Japanese quail learn a category for syllable-initial [d] followed by a dozen different vowels
    • [d], [b], [g]
    • correctly classified syllables in which the consonant preceded the novel vowels

item.title: Statistical and Prosodic Cues for Song Segmentation Learning by Bengalese Finches (Lonchura striata var. domestica)
item.dc:creator: timsainb

item.title: Stepwise Statistical Learning
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Two mechanisms for statistical learning:
    • learning in steps, or learning simultaneously

item.title: Stepwise acquisition of vocal combinatorial capacity in songbirds and human infants
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Study demonstrates that humans and songbirds begin to produce new element transitions in stepwise fashion
  • Three Species
    • zebra finches (Taeniopygia guttata)
    • Bengalese finches (Lonchura striata domestica)
    • pre-lingual human infants
  • Common stepwise acquisition of vocal transitions
  • Study 1
    • zebra finches
    • trained to perform a song
    • training target was altered
    • birds swap syllable order, or insert new syllable into string
    • results
      • birds solved permutations stepwise
  • Study 2
    • bengalese finches
    • bidirectional transitions in song syntax were acquired in stepwise fashion
  • Study 3
    • Infant data
    • Classically
      • babbling starts with reduplicative (repetitive sequences)
      • moves to variegated babbling (diverse sequences)
    • Shifts actually occur in steps
Experiment 1:   Experiment 2: Experiment 3:

item.title: Making Working Memory Work: A Computational Model of Learning in the Prefrontal Cortex and Basal Ganglia
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Randall O'Reilly, Michael J Frank
  • Model of prefrontal cortex (PFC) in working memory
    • pfc, basal ganglia, amygdala
    • Actor-critic architecture
      • critic
        • what pfc representations are task relevant
      • actor
        • provides dynamic gating for controlling working memory updating
  • Attempt at solving temporal and structural credit assignment problems
  • Example: 1-2-AX

item.title: Statistical learning of recurring sound patterns encodes auditory objects in songbird forebrain
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Kai Lua and David S. Vicario
  • Passively exposed birds to long song streams
    • streams contained statistical regularities
      • similar to saffran et al
    • Single and multiunit responses reflect discrimination of familiar from novel patterns
    • discrimination was lateralized (right hemisphere)
    • Response to recurring pattern showed adaptation
  • Used neurons in NCM and CLM
    • which both receive input from field L
 
  • it is still not clear how multiple sound components are integrated over time and recognized as an object

item.title: Songbirds possess the spontaneous ability to discriminate syntactic rules
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• Kentaro Abe1,2 & Dai Watanabe1,3
  • http://www.nature.com/neuro/journal/v14/n8/pdf/nn.2869.pdf
  • Bengalese Finch

item.title: Structural and functional evolution of the basal ganglia in vertebrates
item.dc:creator: timsainb
item.content:encoded:
• http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0165017398000162
  • Anton Reinera, , Loreta Medinab, C.Leo Veenmanc
  • Striatum has largely been conserved between mammals and birds
  • In distal anamniotes (fish and reptiles) basal ganglia mostly influences tectum
  • In mammals, birds, and reptiles, striatum and pallum of the basal ganglia are
    • neuron rich
    • have the same basic populations
    • recieve abundant tegmental dopaminergic cortical input
    • functional circuitry is similar
  • However
    • output to the cortex is more developed in mammals than birds/reptiles
http://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0165017398000162-gr13.gif (sauropsid here is bird)
